big.big: Are you a researcher in Economics or a related field? Create and maintain a public profile of your work.

acis:phrase.p: Registration will not grant you access to any resources, documents or data. Use this page only if you understand the purpose of registering. Read about the service if you don’t.
This is not a search engine. If you want to search for papers and articles, please use EconPapers or IDEAS.
If you already have an account and recently moved, do not create a new account. Log in with your old email address and modify your contact details and affiliation.

acis:phrase.p: Coordinates for an institution listed above incorrect? Please send email to with corrections. Do not remove the affiliation if you have not left this institution.
Please note that removing an item only removes it from your profile, not from the database. Also, we discourage the removal of old versions as links from old to newer versions cannot be established.

li.p: Review your name variations (below). The automatic search will only find documents matching these name variations.

Your name may be misspelled in our bibliographic data. The automatic search will not find papers where your name is misspelled. Try using a manual search. If you know the RePEc handle of a paper of yours, you can use the search on the handle to find it and add it to your profile.
It is likely that the documents you’d like to have listed are not in our database.

acis:phrase.p: To add a work to your research profile, it must already be in our documents database. You cannot add other works yourself. We do not accept individual document submissions. However, you can submit your work to MPRA, that would integrate it in RePEc.
You may wish to check out our New Economics Papers service, the topical mailing lists on new economics research papers and articles.
We can do automatic additions to your citation profile in certain cases (explained below). Here you may disable or enable automatic changes to your profile.
In your monthly mailing from Christian Zimmermann you would see a list of recently found citations. Make sure the following email address is whitelisted at your email service' spam filter:

acis:phrasing.acis:phrase: Note that registration with RePEc <http://repec.org/> will not grant you privileged access to password protected sites. The RePEc Author Service is a tool that allows authors in Economics and related fields to build a CV linking to their works in IDEAS, EconPapers and Socionet, and vice-versa. You will receive a monthly mailing about the popularity of your works on these services. We will also perform some citation analysis for you.

These services are supported by volunteers. Encourage others to sign up as well. And consider subscribing to the NEP reports at http://nep.repec.org/. These reports alert you to new papers in your fields of interest, for free.
For details about the RePEc project and how you can contribute to its success, see http://repec.org/.

We notice that you did not link to any works. There can be two reasons:
1) You registered only to get access to password protected online texts. Registering with the RePEc Author Service is useless for this, you need to register with the sites providing those texts, not RePEc. In such a case, there is no point in registering with RePEc.
2) You did not find any works of yours. This may be because the institutions where you publish do not yet participate in RePEc. Encourage them to do so. See <http://repec.org/>. Or is it that your name may appear with different spellings? In that case, you can confirm now, login and add alternative name spellings to your name variations before performing a new search.
Christian Zimmermann for the RePEc Author Service team
